<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 306, 220, 321]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 327, 304, 344]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Mechanics 2 (M2)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 370, 418, 386]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 392, 460, 408]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 418, 390, 435]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 448, 787, 464]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of this page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 464, 325, 479]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 479, 504, 495]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 495, 504, 510]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 510, 384, 525]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 540, 285, 555]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 555, 910, 585]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 585, 724, 600]]<|/det|>
Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity is needed, use \(10 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 600, 593, 615]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 615, 606, 630]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 644, 608, 660]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 660, 756, 675]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 675, 440, 690]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) of mass \(0.2\mathrm{kg}\) is released from rest at a point \(O\) on a smooth horizontal surface. A horizontal force of magnitude \(t\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{v}}\mathrm{N}\) directed away from \(O\) acts on \(P\), where \(v\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{-1}\) is the velocity of \(P\) at time \(t\) s after release. Find the velocity of \(P\) when \(t = 2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 104, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[339, 87, 692, 242]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 261, 920, 343]]<|/det|>
A uniform solid cone has height \(0.6 \mathrm{m}\) and base radius \(0.2 \mathrm{m}\). A uniform hollow cylinder, open at both ends, has the same dimensions. An object is made by putting the cone inside the cylinder so that the base of the cone coincides with one end of the cylinder (see diagram, which shows a cross-section). The total weight of the object is \(60 \mathrm{N}\) and its centre of mass is \(0.25 \mathrm{m}\) from the base of the cone. Calculate the weight of the cone. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 84, 720, 177]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 196, 920, 265]]<|/det|>
A light elastic string has natural length \(2 \mathrm{~m}\) and modulus of elasticity \(39 \mathrm{~N}\). The ends of the string are attached to fixed points \(A\) and \(B\) which are at the same horizontal level and \(2.4 \mathrm{~m}\) apart. A particle \(P\) of mass \(m \mathrm{~kg}\) is attached to the mid-point of the string and hangs in equilibrium at a point \(0.5 \mathrm{~m}\) below \(AB\) (see diagram).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 275, 156, 293]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 275, 312, 293]]<|/det|>
Show that \(m = 0.9\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 275, 918, 293]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
\(P\) is projected vertically downwards from the equilibrium position, and comes to instantaneous rest at a point \(1.6 \text{m}\) below \(AB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 120, 154, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 120, 465, 138]]<|/det|>
Calculate the speed of projection of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[299, 84, 737, 242]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 260, 920, 327]]<|/det|>
\(OAB\) is a uniform lamina in the shape of a quadrant of a circle with centre \(O\) and radius \(0.8 \text{m}\) which has its centre of mass at \(G\). The lamina is smoothly hinged at \(A\) to a fixed point and is free to rotate in a vertical plane. A horizontal force of magnitude \(12 \text{N}\) acting in the plane of the lamina is applied to the lamina at \(B\). The lamina is in equilibrium with \(AG\) horizontal (see diagram).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 339, 156, 357]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 339, 358, 357]]<|/det|>
Calculate the length \(AG\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 339, 920, 357]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 156, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 400, 91]]<|/det|>
Find the weight of the lamina.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
One end of a light elastic string of natural length \(0.4 \mathrm{~m}\) and modulus of elasticity \(8 \mathrm{~N}\) is attached to a fixed point \(O\) on a smooth horizontal plane. The other end of the string is attached to a particle \(P\) of mass \(0.2 \mathrm{~kg}\) which moves on the plane in a circular path with centre \(O\). The speed of \(P\) is \(v \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\) and the extension of the string is \(x \mathrm{~m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 152, 154, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 151, 364, 170]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\nu = 2.5\), find \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 152, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
It is given instead that the kinetic energy of \(P\) is twice the elastic potential energy stored in the string.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 104, 154, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 104, 620, 122]]<|/det|>
Form two simultaneous equations and hence find \(x\) and \(v\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
\(B\) bounces when it strikes the plane, and leaves the plane with speed \(20 \text{m s}^{-1}\) but with its horizontal component of velocity unchanged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 153, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
Find the total time which elapses between the initial projection of \(B\) and the instant when it strikes the plane for the second time.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]
